entry.title: late colonial, part deux
entry.content:
Hope everyone has a great Thanksgiving. I present to you the last of our online lectures for this semester. It’s been a challenging experiment for me to put these together, and I hope that for the 90% of you who said at the midterm that you prefer having one, the online lectures have continued to prove useful/helpful/etc.

One VERY important note— pay attention to the beginning of the lecture, because I make an announcement that will have direct bearing on your final exam.

Course videos available on iTunes too if the html5 video tag doesn’t work for you.

entry.title: An uneasy peace
entry.content:
Here’s this week’s online lecture— An Uneasy Peace is achieved by the middle of the 17th century as institutions matured, population stabilized, and the household grew to accept a whole variety of forms:

Course videos available on iTunes too if the html5 video tag doesn’t work for you.

No questionnaire for this week! I’m going to ask the questions at the beginning of class on Monday. So take good notes!

entry.title: gender and society
entry.content:
Here’s this week’s online lecture. Pay close attention to the notion that socially, gender relations were organized in a manner analogous to other forms of authority we’ve already looked at. Questionnaire below! Lecture:

Course videos available on iTunes too if the html5 video tag doesn’t work for you.

Questionnaire:

entry.title: Atlantic Slave Economy
entry.content:
And here it is…. At about 30min into the lecture, I ask you to watch the Amistad clip below. Don’t forget to fill out the questionnaire before next Monday!

Course videos available on iTunes too if the html5 video tag doesn’t work for you.

Amistad clip:

Questionnaire:

I would encourage you to spend some time poking around at the Transatlantic Slave Trade Database page to get a feeling for the scope and scale of the Atlantic slave economy.

entry.title: inquisition revisited
entry.content:
Hi everyone—

Well, it appears I had a lot more to say about the inquisition. Here is this week’s video. I mention at the beginning that it will be short, and that I’d be putting up a second short video on the economy. Turns out it’s long, and there isn’t a second one! By the way, there are few slides with text that should be bigger. Because of that I would suggest that you watch the video in full screen mode.

Course videos available on iTunes too if the html5 video tag doesn’t work for you.

And this week’s questionnaire:

Finally— here’s a great scene from Goya’s Ghost that exemplifies the logic of torture and investigation. Javier Bardem, playing a priest of the Holy Office, gets “put to the question.”

entry.title: another go at taming the conquest
entry.content:
Hi everyone—

Here’s this week’s second lecture. I wasn’t happy with how the lecture went after the end of La Otra Conquista, so I’ve backtracked a bit for this one. There’s also a questionnaire for the video at the bottom of this post. Make sure to answer it before next Monday’s in-class meeting.

Course videos available on iTunes too if the html5 video tag doesn’t work for you.

Questionnaire:

entry.title: film review assignment
entry.content:
Hi everyone—

As you will note on the class schedule, your next major assignment is due November 1st. The assignment is a critical review of the film, La otra conquista. Instructions are now posted here.

entry.title: myths of conquest 1
entry.content:
Hi everyone! Here is our last online lecture and questionnaire before the midterm. Please note that next Wednesday you must be in class for your exam, and that on the following Wednesday you need to be in class to finish the movie, La Otra Conquista. I will be posting an exam review later today. It’s almost finished, but not quite in time for putting up this video. When it’s up, it will be linked to from here, and on the Assignments page. (Here is the exam review.)

Lecture:

Course videos available on iTunes too if the html5 video tag doesn’t work for you.

entry.title: Columbus Sails!
entry.content:
Hi everyone—

At long last, the online lecture for Wednesday, September15. Â I’m having problems getting the built in player to work with this file. But, I’m working on. If the video doesn’t want to stream, give it a couple moments to load and try starting it again.

Course videos available on iTunes too if the html5 video tag doesn’t work for you.

Please see the questionnaire below the video and remember that you’re required to complete it before we meet on Monday. Also, if you haven’t already done so, please go here and answer the survey on the online lectures. Hasta lunes!

And here’s this week’s questionnaire:

entry.title: Survey on Online Lectures
entry.content:
Hi History255/LAS 251!

This week’s online lecture will be posted later today (Wednesday). In the meantime, please fill out the survey below on our use of online lectures.

If you remember, on the first day of class I promised that at the middle of the semester we would take a moment to evaluate and reconsider the use of online lectures. In order to do that, I need as much honest feedback from you as I can get leading into the mid-term. I’ve spoken thus far to about 20 of you, but that leaves quite a few. In order to streamline the data collection, please answer the questions below. There are no right or wrong answers here. I really want to hear what you think. So, thanks!

entry.title: map of the central valley of mexico
entry.content:
One of your intrepid classmates asked me to post the map of the alteptls of the central valley. So, here it is!

And, here’s a pdf if you’d like to keep a copy of it for yourself.

Oh, and don’t forget, if you’re accessing the lectures through iTunes U, to come back over here after you’ve watched it and answer the questionnaires I’m providing for the online lectures.

entry.title: the inca
entry.content:
This week, for our online lecture, we turn our attention to the precolombian Andes. After listening to the lecture, if you’re interested in more I’ve also embedded a hulu presentation of a national geographic documentary on Incan mummies. It’s an interesting documentary that tells the tale of the recovery of hundreds of mummies from an area outside of Lima that has become a shanty town. And, as with last week, I’ve added a short reaction form with questions to help you remember some of the important points of the lecture.

One more thing— if you have any problems, I’ve finally set up a space on my forum for you to ask questions.

Our lecture:

Course videos available on iTunes too if the html5 video tag doesn’t work for you.

National Geographic’s:

And, a questionnaire:

entry.title: Maya Images
entry.content:
Updated with Part II and a questionnaire.

Well, after some (for me) significant tech problems trying to embed a video in the video using new recording software, I’ve finally the first half of our lecture on the Maya finished. It should be available on iTunes as well, so if you’ve subscribed it should be showing up in your iTunes U. Part 2 available shortly. Once I get these technical kinks worked out, the quality and performance should improve.

Also, I mention in part one a great documentary on PBS, “Cracking the Maya Code.” You can see it here if you’re interested.

OK, here is Part 1:

And, here is Part 2:

Course videos available on iTunes too if the html5 video tag doesn’t work for you.

When you’ve finished watching, take a stab at these questions:

entry.title: Section 3 Classroom Location
entry.content: If you are in Section 3, the registrar has decided you need exercise. So, your section will be meeting in HPER 31-B. Take your climbing shoes and go bouldering after class!
